sense.name: bound periodical publication
sense.examples: She writes for a sports magazine. I tripped over a pile of old magazines in the hallway. John never reads magazines, he just looks at the pictures. That CEO has been on the cover of several magazines. I try to keep up with a graphics art zine on the Internet.

sense.name: a small supply chamber, e.g., in a gun or camera
sense.examples: She clipped another magazine into her semi-automatic rifle. My camera bag has only two more magazines of film. Spent magazines lay on the floor of the drug dealer's bedroom.

sense.name: a publishing firm or business
sense.examples: Our magazine is merging with a larger European publishing conglomerate. Do you think the magazine will fire him for that story? Sally's dad ran that magazine for years. Magazines and newspapers are going out of business right and left.

sense.name: a warehouse for storing goods, e.g., ammunition
sense.examples: That huge explosion was the magazine for the National Guard. The soldiers, under fire, frantically began moving explosives out of their magazine.

sense.name: a regularly broadcast radio program
sense.examples: We enjoy a Saturday news magazine on the radio. Mary has been invited to host a weekly food magazine on our local radio station.
